title: 103_hr629
content: The Act may be cited as the "Improvement of Information Access Act of 1993". The Congress recognizes the importance of a well-informed citizenry, access to Government information, modern technology utilization, and the value of Government information as a national resource and economic asset. Federal agencies should use modern information technology for affordable access to Government information, which is considered a national resource and valuable economic asset belonging to the public. Taxpayers should not have to pay excessive fees for the creation and organization of Government information. Federal agencies should make it easier for citizens to provide feedback on Federal information policies to ensure public interest is considered. Federal agencies struggle to gather feedback from citizens on information policies, hindering public interest consideration. They are slow in setting standards for data formats and access, leading to difficulties in obtaining government information efficiently and affordably. The text chunk discusses the addition of a new chapter to Title 44, United States Code, focusing on improving public access to government information through information dissemination policies and practices. The text discusses the requirement for executive departments to annually report on their information dissemination policies and practices, including plans for new information products and services. Each year, executive departments must report on their information dissemination policies and practices, including plans for new products and services, efforts to develop standards for easier information access, and progress in these areas. The department or establishment must report on efforts to develop standards for easier information access, creating comprehensive indexes, and methods for public access to information. The report must include creating and disseminating indexes and bibliographies, methods for public access to information, protecting access to outdated records, promoting information resources, and summarizing public comments from the previous year. The report must include provisions for protecting access to records stored with obsolete technologies, methods for making the public aware of information resources, and a summary of public comments from the previous year. Each year, executive departments, military departments, and independent establishments must publish a notice in the Federal Register and other platforms informing the public about the availability of a report on information dissemination policies. The public is given a 90-day period to submit comments on these policies and practices. The public is given a 90-day period to submit comments on information dissemination policies and practices, including types of information collected and methods of dissemination. The public can submit comments on information dissemination policies, including types of information collected, methods of dissemination, prices charged, and validity, reliability, timeliness, and usefulness of the information. The public can submit comments on information dissemination policies, including types of information collected, methods of dissemination, prices charged, and validity, reliability, timeliness, and usefulness of the information. Comments received will be available for public inspection, and there will be opportunities for dialogue between agency officials and the public through hearings and informal forums. The department or establishment must allow public inspection of information. There should be opportunities for dialogue between agency officials and the public through hearings and forums. Before discontinuing an information product or service, the agency must publish a notice in the Federal Register or through other adequate means. Before discontinuing an information product or service, an agency must publish a notice in the Federal Register or through other means, provide a 120-day period for public comments, explain the reasons for discontinuation, and consider the received comments. Each agency is required to establish policies, procedures, and mechanisms for disseminating information and implementing this section. Each agency must provide a 120-day notice for public comments before discontinuing an information product or service, explain the reasons for discontinuation, and consider the received comments. Agencies are also required to disseminate information through various channels to ensure public access to government information. The agency must disseminate information through diverse modes and outlets to reinforce statutory requirements and ensure public access. Information should be timely, useful, and reliable, stored in standardized formats for dissemination. The agency must disseminate Government information to the public through various channels to ensure timeliness, usefulness, and reliability. Information should be stored in standardized formats and distributed through depository libraries and other channels for free or low-cost public access. The agency must disseminate Government information through depository libraries and other channels for free or low-cost public access, without charging fees for distribution or royalties. The Archivist of the United States and the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology are required to distribute government information products and services without charging fees for distribution or royalties. The incremental cost of distributing information products does not include costs of collecting, organizing, or processing the information. The Archivist of the United States and the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology will issue model performance standards for agencies to provide access to public records. Agencies must provide copies of public documents upon request within a specified timeframe. The Archivist of the United States and the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology will issue model performance standards for agencies to provide access to public records, including a timeframe for providing copies of public documents upon request. The Archivist of the United States and the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology will issue model performance standards for providing access to agency records under section 4101(f) of title 44, United States Code within one year of the enactment of this Act.
